answers.text: In the countries of the former Soviet Union the Russian language is gradually being replaced by local languages.

context: According to figures published in <b5_0>2006<b5_0/> in the journal "Demoskop Weekly" <b8_0>research deputy director<b8_0/> of Research Center for Sociological Research of the <a0_0><b7_0>Ministry of Education and Science<b7_0/> (Russia)<a0_0/> Arefyev A. L., the Russian language is gradually losing its <b6_0>position in the world<b6_0/> in general, and in Russia in particular. In <a2_0>2012<a2_0/>, <a1_0>A. L. Arefyev<a1_0/> published a new study <b4_0>"Russian language at the turn of the 20th-21st centuries"<b4_0/>, in which he confirmed his conclusion about the trend of further weakening of the Russian language in all regions of the world (findings published in 2013 in the journal "Demoskop Weekly"). <a3_0>In the countries of the former Soviet Union the Russian language is gradually being replaced by local languages.<a3_0/> Currently the number speakers of Russian language in the world depends on the number of Russians in the world (as the main sources distribution Russian language) and total population Russia (where Russian is an official language).
